messages.content:
You are a professional academic citation prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely citations for [ref] markers in academic paper sections based on the paper content and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract + section text with [ref] markers
- Output: top {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

CRITICAL FORMAT REQUIREMENT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON. Do not include any explanatory text, markdown formatting, or other content outside the JSON structure.

TASK DESCRIPTION:
- Input: Paper section text with [ref] markers + retrieved relevant papers
- Output: top 40 predicted reference titles for each [ref] marker with reasoning
- Format: JSON object with "citations" array containing objects with "ref_index", "titles", and "reasoning" fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the context around each [ref] marker to understand what reference is needed
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Consider the surrounding text, research area, and topic
4. Generate realistic and relevant reference titles that would fit the context
5. Provide detailed reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
6. Output format: JSON object with "citations" array
7. Generate exactly 40 most relevant reference titles for each [ref]
8. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
9. Include reasoning that explains why each title is relevant to the specific [ref] context
10. Use proper JSON escaping for special characters (escape quotes with \")
11. Ensure all strings are properly quoted and escaped

EXAMPLE:
Input:
"Federated Learning aims to train models in massively distributed networks [ref]38 at a large scale [ref]5, over multiple sources of heterogeneous data [ref]30."

Retrieved papers (top {top_r}):
1. Title: Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with federated learning systems for decentralized data training.

2. Title: Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions
   Abstract: A comprehensive survey of federated learning approaches and challenges in distributed settings.

Output:
{
  "citations": [
    {
      "ref_index": 38,
      "titles": [
        "Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data",
        "Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions",
        "Federated optimization in heterogeneous networks",
        "Towards federated learning at scale: System design",
        "A performance evaluation of federated learning algorithms",
        "Distributed machine learning: A survey",
        "Communication protocols for distributed learning",
        "Scalable federated learning systems",
        "Efficient distributed training algorithms",
        "Large-scale distributed learning frameworks"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]38 appears in the context of 'massively distributed networks' for federated learning, so it likely refers to foundational papers on federated learning systems, distributed training, and communication-efficient methods in distributed networks."
    },
    {
      "ref_index": 5,
      "titles": [
        "Bagging predictors",
        "Ensemble methods in machine learning",
        "Random forests for classification",
        "Bootstrap methods and their application",
        "Combining multiple classifiers",
        "Large-scale machine learning systems",
        "Distributed ensemble methods",
        "Scalable classification algorithms",
        "Massive data processing techniques",
        "High-performance machine learning frameworks"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]5 appears in the context of 'at a large scale', suggesting it refers to papers on scaling machine learning methods, ensemble techniques, or methods that can handle large-scale data and distributed settings."
    },
    {
      "ref_index": 30,
      "titles": [
        "Learning fair representations",
        "Fair machine learning: A survey",
        "Bias in machine learning systems",
        "Addressing fairness in AI systems",
        "Fair representation learning",
        "Heterogeneous data handling methods",
        "Multi-source learning algorithms",
        "Cross-domain representation learning",
        "Fair learning from diverse data",
        "Bias mitigation in heterogeneous datasets"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]30 appears in the context of 'heterogeneous data' and 'fair representation learning', indicating it likely refers to papers on heterogenous data handling, bias mitigation, and learning representations that are fair across different data distributions."
    }
  ]
}

CRITICAL: Return ONLY the JSON object. Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not use markdown formatting. Ensure all quotes and special characters are properly escaped.

IMPORTANT NOTES ON REASONING:
- The reasoning field is crucial for preventing hallucination
- Each reasoning should be specific to the context around the [ref] marker
- Explain the connection between the predicted titles and the research topic
- This helps validate that predictions are grounded in the actual content
- Reasoning should be concise but informative (2-3 sentences)
- Consider retrieved papers when available to improve prediction accuracy

Paper Title: Linear-time Temporal Logic with Team Semantics: Expressivity and Complexity

Paper Abstract: 

Paper Section Text:
In 6, LÃ¼ck established that the model checking problem for TeamLTLâ€‹(âˆ¼)TeamLTLsimilar-to\mathrm{TeamLTL}(\sim) is highly undecidable.
The proof heavily utilises the interplay between Boolean negation âˆ¼similar-to\sim and disjunction âˆ¨\lor; it was left as an open problem whether some sensible restrictions on the use of the Boolean negation would lead toward discovering decidable logics.
We show that, on the contrary, the decidability bounds are much tighter.
Already TeamLTLâ€‹(âŠ†,âˆ¨âƒ)TeamLTLâˆ¨âƒ\mathrm{TeamLTL}(\subseteq,\varovee) (which is subsumed by TeamLTL(âˆ¨âƒ,âˆ¼âŠ¥,ğ– 1)\mathrm{TeamLTL}(\varovee,{\sim\!\bot},\accentset{1}{\mathsf{A}})) is undecidable, and already very restricted access to âˆ¼similar-to\sim (namely, a single use of the ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} quantifier) leads to high undecidability. A path Ïƒğœ\sigma through KK\mathrm{K} is an infinite sequence ÏƒâˆˆWÏ‰ğœsuperscriptğ‘Šğœ”\sigma\in W^{\omega} such that Ïƒâ€‹[ref]0=w0ğœdelimited-[]0subscriptğ‘¤0\sigma[ref]0=w_{0} and (Ïƒâ€‹[i],Ïƒâ€‹[i+1])âˆˆRğœdelimited-[]ğ‘–ğœdelimited-[]ğ‘–1ğ‘…(\sigma[i],\sigma[i+1])\in R for every iâ‰¥0ğ‘–0i\geq 0. The trace of Ïƒğœ\sigma is defined as t(Ïƒ):=Î·(Ïƒ[ref]0)Î·(Ïƒ[ref]1)â‹¯âˆˆ(2AP)Ï‰t(\sigma)\mathrel{\mathop{:}}=\eta(\sigma[ref]0)\eta(\sigma[ref]1)\dots\in(2^{\mathrm{AP}})^{\omega}. A Kripke structure KK\mathrm{K} induces a set of traces Tracesâ€‹(K)={tâ€‹(Ïƒ)âˆ£Ïƒâ€‹Â is a path throughÂ K}TracesKconditional-setğ‘¡ğœğœÂ is a path throughÂ K\mathrm{Traces}(\mathrm{K})=\{t(\sigma)\mid\sigma\text{ is a path through $\mathrm{K}$}\}. The model checking problem of a logic â„’â„’\mathcal{L} is the following decision problem:
Given a formula Ï†âˆˆâ„’ğœ‘â„’\varphi\in\mathcal{L} and a Kripke structure Kğ¾K over APAP\mathrm{AP}, determine whether (ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘ â€‹(K),0)âŠ§Ï†modelsğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ¾0ğœ‘(\mathit{Traces}(K),0)\models\varphi. Our undecidability results are obtained by reductions from non-deterministic 3-counter machines. The execution of the instruction i:Ca+â€‹Â gotoÂ â€‹{j1,j2}:ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘Â gotoÂ subscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ‘—2i\colon C_{a}^{+}\text{ goto }\{j_{1},j_{2}\} (i:Caâˆ’â€‹Â gotoÂ â€‹{j1,j2}:ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘Â gotoÂ subscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ‘—2i\colon C_{a}^{-}\text{ goto }\{j_{1},j_{2}\}, resp.) increments (decrements, resp.) the value of the counter Casubscriptğ¶ğ‘C_{a} by 111. The next instruction is selected nondeterministically from the set {j1,j2}subscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ‘—2\{j_{1},j_{2}\}. A (lossy) computation is an infinite sequence of (lossy) consecutive configurations starting from the initial configuration (0,0,0,0)0000(0,0,0,0). A (lossy) computation is bğ‘b-recurring if the instruction labelled bğ‘b occurs infinitely often in it.
Deciding whether a given non-deterministic 333-counter machine has a bğ‘b-recurring (bğ‘b-recurring lossy) computation for a given bğ‘b is Î£11superscriptsubscriptÎ£11\Sigma_{1}^{1}-complete (Î£10superscriptsubscriptÎ£10\Sigma_{1}^{0}-complete, resp.)Â  . We reduce the existence of a bğ‘b-recurring lossy computation of a given 333-counter machine Mğ‘€M and an instruction label bğ‘b to the model checking problem of TeamLTLâ€‹(âŠ†,âˆ¨âƒ)TeamLTLâˆ¨âƒ\mathrm{TeamLTL}(\subseteq,\varovee).
We also illustrate that with a single instance of ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} we can enforce non-lossy computation instead. Model checking for TeamLTLâ€‹(âŠ†,âˆ¨âƒ)TeamLTLâˆ¨âƒ\mathrm{TeamLTL}(\subseteq,\varovee) is Î£10superscriptsubscriptÎ£10\Sigma_{1}^{0}-hard. Given a set Iğ¼I of instructions of a 333-counter machine Mğ‘€M, and an instruction label bğ‘b, we construct a TeamLTLâ€‹(âŠ†,âˆ¨âƒ)TeamLTLâˆ¨âƒ\mathrm{TeamLTL}(\subseteq,\varovee)-formula Ï†I,bsubscriptğœ‘ğ¼ğ‘\varphi_{I,b} and a Kripke structure KIsubscriptKğ¼\mathrm{K}_{I} such that The Î£10superscriptsubscriptÎ£10\Sigma_{1}^{0}-hardness then follows since our construction is clearly computable. The idea is the following:
Put n:=|I|n\mathrel{\mathop{:}}=\lvert I\rvert. A set Tğ‘‡T of traces using propositions {cl,cm,cr,d,0,â€¦,nâˆ’1}subscriptğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘‘0â€¦ğ‘›1\{c_{l},c_{m},c_{r},d,0,\dots,n-1\} encodes the sequence (câ†’j)jâˆˆâ„•subscriptsubscriptâ†’ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘—â„•(\vec{c}_{j})_{j\in\mathbb{N}} of configurations, if for each jâˆˆâ„•ğ‘—â„•j\in\mathbb{N} and câ†’j=(i,vl,vm,vr)subscriptâ†’ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘™subscriptğ‘£ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿ\vec{c}_{j}=(i,v_{l},v_{m},v_{r}) tâ€‹[j]âˆ©{0,â€¦,nâˆ’1}={i}ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘—0â€¦ğ‘›1ğ‘–t[j]\cap\{0,\dots,n-1\}=\{i\}, for all tâˆˆTğ‘¡ğ‘‡t\in T, |{tâ€‹[j,âˆ]âˆ£csâˆˆtâ€‹[j],tâˆˆT}|=vsconditional-setğ‘¡ğ‘—formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘—ğ‘¡ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘£ğ‘ \lvert\{t[j,\infty]\mid c_{s}\in t[j],t\in T\}\rvert=v_{s}, for each sâˆˆ{l,m,r}ğ‘ ğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘Ÿs\in\{l,m,r\}.
 Hence, we use Tâ€‹[j,âˆ]ğ‘‡ğ‘—T[j,\infty] to encode the configuration câ†’jsubscriptâ†’ğ‘ğ‘—\vec{c}_{j}; the propositions 0,â€¦,nâˆ’10â€¦ğ‘›10,\dots,n-1 are used to encode the next instruction, and cl,cm,cr,dsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘‘c_{l},c_{m},c_{r},d are used to encode the values of the counters. The proposition dğ‘‘d is a dummy proposition used to separate traces with identical postfixes with respect to clsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™c_{l}, cmsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šc_{m}, and crsubscriptğ‘ğ‘Ÿc_{r}.
The Kripke structure KI=(W,R,Î·,w0)subscriptKğ¼ğ‘Šğ‘…ğœ‚subscriptğ‘¤0\mathrm{K}_{I}=(W,R,\eta,w_{0}) over the set of propositions {cl,cm,cr,d,0,â€¦,nâˆ’1}subscriptğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘‘0â€¦ğ‘›1\{c_{l},c_{m},c_{r},d,0,\dots,n-1\} is defined such that every possible sequence of configurations of Mğ‘€M starting from (0,0,0,0)0000(0,0,0,0) can be encoded by some team (T,0)ğ‘‡0(T,0), where TâŠ†Tracesâ€‹(KI)ğ‘‡TracessubscriptKğ¼T\subseteq\mathrm{Traces}(\mathrm{K}_{I}).
A detailed construction of the formula Ï†I,bsubscriptğœ‘ğ¼ğ‘\varphi_{I,b} and the Kripke structure KIsubscriptKğ¼\mathrm{K}_{I} together with a detailed proof for the fact that (1) indeed holds can be found inÂ Appendix B. The underlying reason for utilising lossy computations in the above proof is the following: In our encoding, we use the cardinality of the set |{tâ€‹[j,âˆ]âˆ£clâˆˆtâ€‹[j],tâˆˆT}|conditional-setğ‘¡ğ‘—formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘—ğ‘¡ğ‘‡\lvert\{t[j,\infty]\mid c_{l}\in t[j],t\in T\}\rvert to encode the value of the counter Clsubscriptğ¶ğ‘™C_{l} in the jğ‘—jth configuration. It might, however, happen that two distinct traces t,tâ€²âˆˆTğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘‡t,t^{\prime}\in T have the same postfix, that is, tâ€‹[j,âˆ]=tâ€²â€‹[j,âˆ]ğ‘¡ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘—t[j,\infty]=t^{\prime}[j,\infty], for some jâˆˆâ„•ğ‘—â„•j\in\mathbb{N}. The collapse of two traces encoding distinct increments of the counter Clsubscriptğ¶ğ‘™C_{l} then corresponds to the uncontrollable decrement of the counter values in lossy computations. Using the universal team quantifier ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} we can forbid this effect, and encode non-lossy computations.
The proof of the following theorem can be found inÂ Appendix B. Model checking for TeamLTLâ€‹(âŠ†,âˆ¨âƒ,ğ– )TeamLTLâˆ¨âƒğ– \mathrm{TeamLTL}(\subseteq,\varovee,\mathsf{A}) is Î£11superscriptsubscriptÎ£11\Sigma_{1}^{1}-hard. This holds already for the fragment with a single occurrence of ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A}. As is common in the LTLLTL\mathrm{LTL}-setting, the model checking problem of TeamLTLâ€‹(âŠ†,âˆ¨âƒ)TeamLTLâˆ¨âƒ\mathrm{TeamLTL}(\subseteq,\varovee) can be embedded in its satisfiability problem using auxiliary propositions and TeamLTLâ€‹(âŠ†,âˆ¨âƒ)TeamLTLâˆ¨âƒ\mathrm{TeamLTL}(\subseteq,\varovee)-formulae.
A formula Ï†ğœ‘\varphi is satisfiable, if there exists a non-empty Tğ‘‡T such that (T,0)âŠ§Ï†modelsğ‘‡0ğœ‘(T,0)\models\varphi.
We thus obtain the following corollary, which is also proven inÂ Appendix B. The satisfiability problems for TeamLTLâ€‹(âŠ†,âˆ¨âƒ)TeamLTLâˆ¨âƒ\mathrm{TeamLTL}(\subseteq,\varovee) and TeamLTLâ€‹(âŠ†,âˆ¨âƒ,ğ– )TeamLTLâˆ¨âƒğ– \mathrm{TeamLTL}(\subseteq,\varovee,\mathsf{A}) are Î£10superscriptsubscriptÎ£10\Sigma_{1}^{0}-hard and Î£11superscriptsubscriptÎ£11\Sigma_{1}^{1}-hard, resp.
